11:17 am
BE11:17am

Commitments to restart trade negotiations, resume certain shipments to Huawei, and a pause in the next round of tariffs, as well as one from
China to purchase U.S. agricultural products are all the result of a Trump-Xi meeting at the G20 over the weekend. Following these positive trade
headlines, President Trump made a surprise visit to the border between North and South Korea and became the first U.S. leader to step on North
Korean territory. The immediate market reaction will be positive as these actions will be viewed as de-escalating the recent U.S.-China tensions
and thus geopolitical risk. There will be a view that the “Trump put” continues with his focus on the market implications of his actions. Politically,
we expect a significant backlash from the Huawei decision. Longer term, nothing really changed in the U.S.-China trade war, and we expect
renewed tensions in the coming weeks/months.
Trump-Xi meeting. The near-term de-escalation of the U.S.-China trade war and the Huawei announcement provide significant positive market
headlines. However, much like the last Trump-Xi meeting last November, the meeting did not really change the fundamentals of this fight. The
China hard liners within Trump's Administration had a tough weekend, but they are still in charge of the negotiations. The media coverage of
the G20 summit and congressional reaction will likely shape President Trump’s next moves. Tariff escalations and tech restrictions still remain
extremely likely over the coming weeks/months, but that threat will likely be discounted (potentially significantly) by the market until signs emerge
of Trump seeking to restart the fight.

BE11:17am

Huawei backlash coming? The statement by President Trump that “U.S. companies can sell their equipment to Huawei. We’re talking about
equipment where there’s no great national security problem with it,” will face significant political push back on Capitol Hill and we believe it
is likely that Congress will seek to overturn this decision based on the 2020 Defense Authorization Act. Few details have emerged on the exact
parameters of what can or cannot be sold, but there has been real concern expressed that President Trump is linking commercial trade with a
national security issue, the likely focus of Congressional activity. Should Trump follow-through on this provision, Huawei likely stays on the entity
list, but the Commerce Department would make more licenses available to U.S. companies to sell certain goods to the company.

BE11:17am

No timeline: good or bad? One of the unsettled questions coming out of the weekend is what’s next? No time line was given for the next round
of talks, no deadline was set for a deal, and no threat was imposed on the next round of tariffs taking effect. We believe that this will be viewed
a near-term positive. The lack of a looming 30, 60, 90-day timeline could allow negotiations to continue without the threat of a due date. Longer
term, we fully expect President Trump to return to the use of trade deadlines to spur activity, capture the press narrative, and ultimately levy more
tariffs on Chinese goods/restrictions on technology.
North Korea. Marking the first time a U.S. President has stepped onto North Korean soil, President Trump followed the G20 meetings with a visit
with North Korean leader, Kim Jong Un. The unprecedented nature of the action will drive much of the media coverage in the coming days, and
could serve to blunt some Congressional criticism related to the Huawei decision. The meeting was promoted as a restart of the denuclearization
talks. The timing of the meeting is unusual, given the recent actions of North Korea to launch short-range missiles in May and increasing concerns
by the Trump Administration related to Iran's nuclear ambitions. We believe these mixed messages will cause considerable concern on Capitol
Hill, but are also likely to be viewed as a de-escalation of some of the growing geopolitical tensions. Only time will tell if this will be short-lived
or mark a shift in U.S. strategy.

11:17 am
JP11:18am

DB's Jim Reid, like us, feels it all a bit meh:

JP11:18am

The main G-20 summit was a sideshow really and the released communique was unanimous only by being bland and not committing anyone to anything. Disagreements on trade and climate change continue. As for the main event, although expectations were building ahead of the Trump/Xi meeting, on balance they exceeded them even if it still feels like a fragile equilibrium. At the moment I’m relieved we went back to being more constructive on credit a couple of weeks ago as news of this meeting broke at the same time as Draghi’s very dovish Sintra speech. The two most positive things from the weekend were that President Trump won’t put the additional tariffs on China for the “time being” and that he softened his stance on Huawei. He will allow US companies to sell some equipment to Huawei, as long as it was “no great national security problem”. At the moment there is no clarity on whether this means Huawei will be taken off the ‘entity list’ of the US Commerce Department, but Trump has promised to discuss this soon and suggested they’ll leave this controversial issue to the end of trade negotiations which is likely to be seen as a positive as its now not standing in the way of an outline deal. However, Trump’s decision to grant Huawei some temporary relief has drawn criticism back home with Senator Marco Rubio tweeting “If President Trump has agreed to reverse recent sanctions against #Huawei he has made a catastrophic mistake.”

JP11:18am

Trump also said Xi promised that China will buy “tremendous” amounts of US agricultural products, and that the US will “give them a list of things” they would like China to buy. However, Chinese official media reports are not as clear on this and suggested only that Trump hopes China will import more American goods as part of the trade-war truce. Meanwhile, there has been no official communication from China. So whether China sees things the same way is not clear, but on balance it seems a more positive backdrop for talks to continue even if there is not currently any roadmap. Elsewhere, Trump continued his criticism of the Fed over the weekend saying the Federal Reserve “has not been of help to us at all” in his trade spat with Beijing and added “Despite that, we’re winning, and we’re winning big because we have created an economy that is second to none”.

BE11:20am

In our opinion, it is not clear that China made significant concessions to restart negotiations. China had previously committed to increase purchases of US products. While the broad contours of the G20 meeting were in line with our expectations, Trump appeared to go somewhat further than we anticipated to get negotiations restarted. This may indicate Trump’s intention to reach an agreement ahead of the 2020 presidential election. However, we continue to believe that a hard stance against China during the negotiations is more politically beneficial for President Trump than a deal that could potentially be perceived as “weak.”

FATDAZ @Excel that should probably be the case ie down from here but .......
BE11:21am

Despite the “positive” outcome of the meeting, we see little evidence that any progress has been made in bridging the gap between the two sides on key, long-standing issues. For example, many points of contention, such as forced technology transfer and other China trade practices, remain unresolved.
Moreover, we do not think the position of the US with respect to Huawei has fundamentally changed. It is unclear how far the US is willing to ease restrictions on Huawei in addition to potentially removing the company from the Entity List, considering quick criticism from Congress. We continue to believe that the most likely outcome will ultimately be a failure to reach a breakthrough and that the US will move ahead with additional tariffs on essentially the remainder of US imports from China at a rate of 25%. This lingering trade policy uncertainty, in addition to softening economic momentum, means that we remain comfortable with our forecast of two interest rate cuts of 25bp each from the Fed this year in July and December.

11:21 am
JP11:21am

UBS also in the "chillax bro" camp:

JP11:22am

G20 verdict: As hoped, but given high risks of the contrary, still a reliefGoing to Osaka, market pricing of trade tensions risk had already fallen to optimistic levels recorded after the December G20 meeting in Buenos Aires. The weekend's events have largely played out in line with expectations, therefore. The reprieve Huawei earned, however low on details, can be seen as an incremental positive (although this was reportedly a precondition to engage from the Chinese side). A below-consensus China PMI and possibility that (post G20) the Fed may offer less support, may dent part of the market enthusiasm. Still, the left tail for global economic outcomes has thinned in the last 48 hours. Helped also by the hope that China will continue with the increased pace of stimulus, risk assets may strengthen in the near term.

JP11:22am

Equities: Rotation to cyclicals to extend; Tech, Fins, energy and EM to benefitUnder a seemingly lofty surface, the "price for safety" in equities had hit extreme levels ahead of Trump-Xi meeting. The G20 result should further the rotation across sectors and factors, assuming data is not much worse than feared. Tech should outperform, helped by loosening of Huawei restrictions. Financials have lagged and should benefit on the margin. Energy was hurt most and may now benefit further, given Russia+OPEC extended production cuts. Lastly, the rotation out of low beta and low vol stocks to cyclicals and value can extend. We turned positive on EM equities tactically after the June Fed meeting, and stick with this position after this weekend, with China equities unwinding a large trade penalty, and additionally benefitting from policy easing domestically. Longer-term we remain cautious EM equities, amidst few signs of growth pick up globally, and even fewer signs of China stimulus boosting the global trade.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good H1 only for the maddening crowds.
11:22 am
JP11:22am

FX: Not a USD trade. APAC to gain modestly. Hedges (JPY, CHF, Gold) to suffer.The G20 meeting result is unlikely to trigger new, lasting trends in G10 FX. Reduction of tail risks should weigh on the USD (but also JPY and CHF), but the prospect of fewer Fed cuts may counterbalance. The EUR is unlikely to benefit; subdued growth and inflation expectations anchor dovish policy expectations. Elsewhere in G10, a decline in trade related risk premium is likely to benefit small open economies such as SEK and NOK, as well as certain G10 commodity exporters AUD and CAD. We are tactically short EUR/SEK. Within EM, this weekend's outcome looks best for CNH, which is likely to unwind part of its trade risk premium; and worst for high carry oil importers (TRY, INR) that are sensitive to higher UST. Low carry growth sensitive FX (KRW, TWD) and oil exporters (RUB, COP) should also benefit near term. Yet, if the upcoming global PMIs remain weak, the rotation from EM carry to EM growth FX may prove short-lived.

Grouchmonkey @JP link does not work?
BE11:25am

[I]n essence this takes away the biggest risk on the Apple story (for now) in our opinion. All the mathematical gymnastics and doomsday predictors over the last few months has convinced the Street that at least roughly ~$2.00 of EPS in FY2020/FY2021 would vanish from the Apple story
given the increased tariffs/costs on the horizon with the company's flagship iPhone Foxconn facility at the centerpiece of the debate. We continue to believe that Apple does not look at diversifying production outside of China (e.g. Vietnam, India) going forward IF the current negotiations stay on track on the threat of the $325 billion tariffs staying pure noise and not becoming a reality. While demand issues
continue to not be ideal for Apple in China (although we believe the company saw a rebound this quarter vs. the prior few quarters), with roughly 60 million to 70 million iPhones in China coming up for an upgrade opportunity over the next 12 to 18 months this region remains a linchpin of growth for the Apple story.
From a scenario perspective, we believe a resolution to the China tariff situation could add between $20-$25 per share to Apple's stock over the coming months in our opinion, as this would take away the dark cloud currently shadowing the stock.

While many on the Street still need to see what FY3Q (June) results look like specifically out of the China region with many yelling fire in a crowded theater, we believe this weekend's developments out of the G20 starts to remove the albatross around Cook's neck which remains the China trade war situation. Taking a step back, there is still more wood to chop ahead for Apple and Cook around seeing a rebound in iPhone demand globally and continued strength in its services business which we believe is key to the overall valuation, however we are incrementally more positive on the stock following developments from the G20 meeting on the tariff front . We maintain our OUTPERFORM rating and $235 price target.

Our thesis on Hurricane is that gradual de-risking of its 2C resource base offers significant share upside. This morning, we learnt that the first and riskiest well in this summer's threewell drilling programme has failed to flow commercial hydrocarbons. At this early stage of interpreting data from the well we make no changes to estimates, nor our 130p target price, although perceptions of the blue-sky upside potential (which does not yet contribute to our target price) could be negatively affected by this news.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

•
Can oil be recovered in other fields from below structural closure? Resource
estimates across HUR's portfolio ascribe significant volumes to oil below structural
closure. From the May 2017 Lancaster CPR: "Hurricane consider[s] [no producible oil
below structural closure] to be extremely unlikely given the wealth of data that supports
[it]", including (i) moveable oil from swabbing 220m below structural closure and (ii)
fluid samples from formation testing tools. At Lancaster, the key test is production data
over a period of c.12 months, and one month in, the EPS is said this morning to be
performing in line with guidance. As a reminder, first oil was declared on June 5 and
guidance is for 9 kb/d during the first three months of production, i.e. 20 k/d flow rates
at 45% average uptime.

• We assign 32p/shr to Core NAV, which includes the Lancaster Early Production System [EPS] risked at 85% plus corporate items. This is not affected by today's news.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

• Our Contingent asset base includes full-field developments of c.500M boe each at Lancaster (71p risked) and Greater Warwick (GWA, 23p risked), each risked at 50%. If Warwick were to turn out non-commercial after the second well, Lincoln (the other component of GWA) has a resource estimate of 566M bbls so could support the envisaged development on a standalone basis, if the resource there is proved up. Lincoln will be the subject of further appraisal with the next well in the programme.
• Our upside NAV, not yet contributing to our target price, attributes value to the c.1.2B bbls of resource at Halifax and the upside case for GWA. The impact on the GWA component of this value (55p/shr risked) will require a fuller assessment of the data, we believe, likely forthcoming at the July 11 CMD.

JP11:36am

Here's Peel Hunt:

11:36 am
JP11:36am

Hurricane Energy today released an update on the Warwick Deep E&A well. The well drilled a 712m horizontal section of fractured basement reservoir, however the well did not flow at commercial rates, producing a mixture of brine, water, oil and gas. Initial analysis indicates that the well intersected a poorly connected section of the fracture network within the oil column and the well will now be plugged and abandoned. Given Warwick Deep tests the same fractured basement reservoir interval as the Lancaster field (separated by the Brynhild fault zone), we see negative read across to reservoir quality risk in the Lancaster field. The rig will next move to drill the Lincoln Crestal well, the second of a three well programme on the Greater Warwick area. Hurricane has a 50% interest in the Greater Warwick area following Spirit Energy's 2018 farm in. Hurricane has a CMD on 11th July when it will provide a further update on analysis of the Warwick Deep well.

BE11:37am

RBC:

11:37 am
BE11:37am

We included ~4p/share for the well in our 127p/share Hurricane NAV.

Today's announcement from Hurricane is disappointing, and we expect the share price reaction to reflect this. However, it does not undermine the next two wells scheduled to be drilled by operator Spirit Energy in the Greater Warwick Area (HUR 50%), nor does it impact the potential scale and deliverability of the Lancaster EPS (HUR 100%). Hurricane is scheduled to host a Capital Markets Day on 11th July in London.

Future announces a trading update today which shows that there has been a continuation of positive trends seen in H1, therefore full year results are expected to be ahead of expectations. The performance has been driven by good audience growth which is driving Media division revenues. Recent acquisition have also performed strongly. On our initial estimates, FY19 EPS will increase by 7% to 40.7p (company adjusted basis). Additionally, Future has announced that Penny Ladkin-Brand will step down from her role as CFO from 1 January 2020 and move to the role of Chief Strategy Officer. The board has commenced a search for Penny’s replacement.

BE11:47am

Future has this morning released a very encouraging trading update that confirms that trading through Q3 has continued the positive trends seen in H1. As a result full year results are expected to be ahead of expectations. We increase estimates in both 2019 and 2020 on the back of this update, with target up to 1,170p. Future remains a key pick for us in 2019, we reiterate our BUY, see recent share price weakness as unjustified and representing a good buying opportunity.

11:55 am
JP11:55am

And some colour on commodities from HSBC:

JP11:55am

Commodity prices were lower overall in June, with our indicator falling by 4% m-o-m (Chart 1). That leaves the overall price level broadly in line with where it ended 2018, but 13% lower than year-ago levels. Concerns over the global growth outlook weighed on prices during late May and most of June, before sentiment improved a little late in the month. The price falls were largely amongst energy and industrial commodities, while soft commodities and precious metals fared better. Of the 42 commodities we monitor, 20 had a lower average price compared to the previous month, while 20 had higher prices, on average.

The major energy commodities all had sharply lower prices in June (Chart 2). Thermal coal prices were down 15% m-o-m, while both natural gas and oil prices were down 11%. Most of the decline in oil prices actually took place over the final two days of May, when Brent crude fell from USD70 per barrel to USD64. That followed strong US inventory data and a further escalation in trade tensions. The price then spent most of May tracking around USD60-62, before lifting to USD66 by month-end. OPEC members are widely expected to maintain production cuts at a scheduled meeting at the beginning of July.

JP11:55am

Metals prices were also broadly lower, with aluminium and nickel both down 1% m-o-m, copper down 2%, and zinc falling by 5%. Like oil, most of these commodities did see prices strengthen a little towards the end of the month as sentiment improved slightly heading into the G20 meetings, at which the US and China were set to resume trade negotiations. Once again, iron ore was the outperformer, with prices up a further 12% m-o-m.

Grains led price gains for the majority of the 'soft' commodities. Wheat prices were up 11% m-o-m, on average, while corn was up 15% and soybeans by 7%. Most of these gains reflected the surge in prices seen during May, as it became apparent that poor weather was delaying plantings in key farming regions of the US, which is likely to have adverse consequences on the quality and quantity of this year's harvest (as we discussed in last month's Snapshot, published on 3 June).

BE11:59am

Thanks re Telit.

BE11:59am

London, 1 July 2019 - Telit Communications PLC ("Telit", the "Company", AIM: TCM), a global enabler of the Internet of Things (IoT), has agreed settlement terms with the London Stock Exchange plc (the "Exchange") for a public censure and fine of £350,000 (waived in full), for breaches of rules 3 and 31 of the AIM Rules for Companies.

The events leading up to the censure relate to the actions of Oozi Cats, who was the CEO at the time of the Company's Admission to AIM up until his resignation in August 2017. The censure relates specifically to the Company's failures of disclosure regarding his indictment in the US or previous variations of his name.

Telit has subsequently entirely reconstituted its Board and as noted in the Exchange's statement, has fully cooperated in its investigation.

The Exchange recognised that, in the particular circumstances of this case, the Company and its advisers faced real difficulties in being able to reasonably uncover information relating to the former CEO's historical indictment.

Given these specific circumstances, the Exchange have decided to waive the fine in full. Further details of the Exchange's findings can be viewed here: AIM Notices
